I don't believe ""cis"" and ""trans"" have substantive content. I do not believe that a male, with male anatomy from head to toe, is a ""woman"" simply having stated that he identifies as such. I also do not believe that genital mutilation surgery makes a male any more of a woman or vice versa. I simply do not believe it. The scientific community is divided on whether 'transgender' identity issues are rooted in mental illness or not, and of course the sociological and philosophical worlds are sharply divided between postmodernists and realists, the former believing that things like ""man"" and ""woman"" are ""social constructs"" while the latter tend to believe - in my opinion with far greater evidence - that gender identity and biological sex do not vary randomly but in fact tend to match overwhelmingly, with extremely rare exceptions. There is no 'spectrum'.  Long story short I do not believe these new ""identities"" are legitimate. That is my opinion. Will the law FORCE me to say otherwise now?

I am a straight Catholic woman living in community with two gay women, one of them also Catholic. We are all professionals with more than a hundred years of service to the community between us. I know nothing of their ""bedroom activities"", as Tom Z sums up their identity as gay women. They are not interested in having anyone know anything about their ""bedroom activities"". Asked about their lives, they speak of the essential work they do in the community (we are a social worker, a doctor and a lawyer) and the loving home life that fills and heals their hearts and souls, allowing them to serve the community the next day. For people like Tom Z, they announce their ""bedroom activities"" when they introduce themselves as a family. For me, when they identify themselves as a loving family committed to serving the community, they announce the beauty of family and the shared joy of serving the community, EVEN the people who reject them. They are the most Christian, generous women I know.

It is not that simple, people can eat & live a perfect healthy lifestyle & still get sick or an illness like Rheumatoid Arthritis.  There is always the question whether a person's illness is caused by environment or genetics.  For some the reason is purely genetic & they will get sick no matter what.   RA is an auto-immune disease & it is genetic but there might be an environmental trigger like vog, stress, poor diet, etc.  Either way there is no real cure for RA just improved treatment for pain and reduce the self-destruction of joints and greatly reduced quality of life.   Better nutrition for everyone is always good but you still need doctors, nurses & a place for people, including the neighbor islands to get treated for various health problems WITHOUT the place going bankrupt.  The neighbor island hospitals when they where run by the State provided that service but went bankrupt using Hawaii tax money & most have been taken over by Queens or Kaiser.   Everything coming down to $$..

""...she offers no empirical basis or evidence for her conclusions...regarding the Anglican church!""  Well, your opinion is not unprecedented. To each his own, especially in a post!  You can read the whole article in ABC RELIGION AND ETHICS, 8 Nov. 2016. Woodhead does base her research on the 2015 British Election Study, which noted that less than a third of UK people identity as Anglican, whose average age is 54; that the Anglican population plunged from 44.5% in 1983 to 19% this past year. Other studies have noted that the 2000 pre-Reformation Churches in England have fewer than 10 worshippers, and 8,000 more can barely muster 20.  Also, we have the warning of the former archbishop of Canterbury, G. Carey: the Church of England is ""a generation away from extinction."" So I don't think her conclusions have no basis at all; her study makes good  use of the GOVERNMENT charts of decline. (Gov.  charts do count since the Church of England is a state church, an arm of the government.)

Many state lotteries (WA lottery included) have never been dedicated solely to education funding. Many people (myself included) thought that the WA lottery was created to fund education, but the bills that were proposed in the 1970's in the WA legislature, did not pass. The first successful move toward dedicating lottery funds for education came on Nov. 7, 2000 when Initiative 728 was approved. This measure redirected part of the lottery revenue to the Student Achievement Fund, which was created by the initiative to reduce class sizes. There have been diversions of those lottery funds to the state's general fund due to projected and real budget short-falls.  Is it possible that the WA State Lottery could be used to fully fund or even have a major impact on education funding in our state? The answer is a resounding ""No""! In 2008 WA state budget analysts reported lottery proceeds would run schools in Washington for less than two days. (source: WA State House Republican website)

Pure democracy is a form of government in which people vote on all policy initiatives directly.  Guaranteeing the election of the presidential candidate with the most popular votes and the majority of Electoral College votes (as the National Popular Vote bill would) would not make us a pure democracy.  Equal representation of the states in the U.S. Senate is explicitly established in the U.S. Constitution. This feature cannot be changed by state law or an interstate compact.  In contrast, the U.S. Constitution explicitly assigns the power of selecting the manner of appointing presidential electors to the states. The enactment by a state legislature of the National Popular Vote bill is an exercise of a legislature‚Äôs existing powers under the U.S. Constitution.  Adding up votes of all voters and winning with the most popular votes is the method that is used in virtually every other election in the country.

Most companies today, not just in the oil and gas sector, are laser focused on near-term earnings (profits) that they can report to their shareholders in the next quarterly report. Most shareholders want and expect more and higher profits each and every quarter. This reality prompts companies to eliminate or underfund investments in areas such as employee training, infrastructure maintenance and safety. These areas hurt the near-term bottom line, but are critical investments in any company's bottom line and success over time. It's a classic case of pay me now (fines, spill clean-up cost, employee medical costs etc) or pay me not later but less over time. Companies, their employees and the environment will all benefit from near-term investments that will insure greater profitability over time.

The wealth management industry conflates two separate services - portfolio management which is now a commodity which an algorithm can look after and  is worth, maybe 0.25% of assets under management, and financial advice or planning which can be of enormous value and is purchased by hourly rate charges or a flat fee. Too often investors are being charged 1-2% of assets under management for portfolio management which is worth perhaps 0.25%, and getting no advice. Yours seems a rather benign view of chemical weapons. Agreed, conventional weapons can be indiscriminate but need not always be so.  Precision strikes and restraint are possible (such as the most recent attack on Syrian targets appears to have been). Chemical weapons by their very nature are always indiscriminate. They may dissipate but in the process of doing so only increase casualties.  This inability to be 'targeted' is one reason they were banned in the first place. As far as being used for propaganda purposes this latest chemical assault assault on Syrian civilians is not an isolated incident. As I said, there have been 9 such attacks this year alone.  There has been long standing agreement that their use was beyond the pale - something the Syrians conceded when they agreed to ""destroy"" their arsenal. Land mines have been a long standing scourge and were addressed via the Ottawa Treaty (1997). AFAIK, we no longer see the sowing of these weapons as in Cambodia and other theatres.

Like you, I had a most remarkable history teacher: Mr. Klein (aka Mr. Clean) at Lachine High. He would act out little vignettes to illustrate various points (eg. what King Ferdinand and Columbus might have said to each other) and was notoriously easy to sidetrack which we delighted in because his stories when side-tracked were much more interesting than what he was supposed to be teaching.  That said, we had great respect for him and when he got 'mad' at us for sidetracking him and said that we had to focus and work faster we'd buckle right down.  He also handed out constructive consequences for misbehaviour. In my case he said, ""Mr. Munroe (he always called us Mr or Miss when we were in trouble), you will write for me by Monday morning a 1,000 word essay on the causes of the First World War.""  Two years later, on our Provincial exam, the 20 point essay question was, ""What were the main causes of the First World War?"" and it all came back to me. He knew... thank you, Mr. Klein.

I wouldn't be unhappy were the Libs to reinstate Harper's policy on the retirement ago because that policy wouldn't affect me. But that's the point, isn't it? We oppose policies that adversely affect us and shrug our shoulders about ones that don't. But there are a lot of collateral issues related to raising the retirement age. For instance, is the government prepared to do anything about discrimination against older unemployed workers? Will it do anything to ensure that those under 67, and particularly those between 55 and 67, have access to necessary medications? Will it ensure that those who are under 67 and are ill and/or disabled have access to adequate incomes? As someone who's over 60 but under 67 and has over the past couple years experienced considerable non-lifestyle-related (i.e. not a smoker or drinker and not significantly overweight) deterioration in my health, it's clear to me that aging has its drawbacks. Not all will make it to 67 before things go horribly wrong.

People over age 45 winning (or almost winning) majors is very rare.  Watson at the 09 Open on a course and terrain that he loved, Nicklaus winning at the Masters at 46 on a course he dominated for years, and Norman in the 08 Open in which he only won two majors in his career and both were in the Open.  In other words, 3 of the all time greats won or contended on majors on tracks for which they had a special affinity or aptitude.  This is the reality Tiger Woods faces as he ages with a rebuilt back, knee, among a wide range of other injuries over the years.  His ability to contend will be very course and circumstance specific when he has a special week.  The convergence of all those issues makes it highly unlikely he can do it.  I am not a Kelly fan but he accurately (surprisingly!) captured the situation with Tiger Woods.

No doubt. He clearly wanted to help Law save face. But the point is that Massachusetts could have sought to have him extradited and didn't. If they had, it would have been fascinating to see how John Paul responded.  My personal opinion is that John Paul had the traditional old world mindset about church-state relations, which would be natural for a prelate from a communist country. I think he believed that, always and everywhere, the church must be protected from the state. So if a bishop is in danger of prosecution in his home country, you get him out, no questions asked.  The problem, of course, is that sometimes the state isn't the bad guy. There's a big difference between a bishop being imprisoned due to lack of religious freedom in China and one on the lam because he dropped the ball on child protection in the U.S. But, sadly, I don't think John Paul was able to make that distinction.

Bob: When I was a boy and young man, the man whose name appears on the front of the State capitol building in Juneau used join me for walks after work sometimes when he visited Sitka on state business. Nice guy, war hero, and secretary to Alaska's constitution: thrifty and honorable to a T.  If memory serves me correctly, after our walks, he would go to the (Sitka Hotel) with his brief case for the night. This hotel is or was the least expensive hotel in town, often inhabited by street people, and ner-do-wells of all sorts. Also fearless. He was one of my dad's colleagues and friends. When I went through my dad's things after he passed, I came across his wallet: It was held together with layers of scotch tape. Territorial guys who knew the  value of a dime.  Contrast this with travel such as this and the $70,000 Suburban with a fancy new painted logo on the side that is driven by the administrator of Southeast Island School District, a job you held a few years ago.  Drain the swamp!

This is because the companies and individuals that used to buy newspaper ads are now buying Facebook and Google ads.  The cost of a newspaper subscription or single copy purchase has NEVER in the history of newspapers been enough to cover the expense of paying all the journalists, photographers and editors required to produce that paper. Those costs have ALWAYS been paid for with advertising sales. If every Canadian over the age of 12 had a newspaper subscription, the industry would still have a revenue problem.

Of course there is no compelling reason why we need a Canada Infrastructure Bank, but the analysis is Azfar Ali Khan and Randall Bartlett is absolute nonsense based on the usual gibberish of the left. First, the analysis of Canada's net debt to GDP.  In measuring net debt the federal government includes the value of CPP, QPP and other pension plans as assets to offset liabilities.  Since the assets of the pension plans belong to the contributors, it is fraudulent (if the government was a private corporation) to include these asset as their own. Second, governments use private sector to fund projects  at higher interest rates to shift the risk to the private sector.  Ontario  has saved millions using alternative financing. (e.g. Oakville hospital built on time and on budget, Metorlinx funding Burlington GO station; years late and  40% over budget). Borrowing to build infrastructure is not a balance sheet activity.  These people need to take economics 101.

""farming was going great guns in Greenland""  No, it wasn't. There were two marginal settlements in southern Greenland raising cattle, pigs, goats and sheep and hunting walrus, whales and polar bears. Experiments to grow barley failed, so all that was grown was winter silage for the animals. Eventually the cattle and pigs died off, and the goats and sheep dwindled. The Norse settlers slowly switched to a diet rich in seal and fish, dwindled in numbers themselves, and by the early 1400s had either returned to Iceland and Norway (both depopulated by plague) or died off.

You raise an interesting point about what parents would do if they didn't have a math background.  They'd just have to depend on the schools to cover the subject.  But the fact is, the majority of parents don't have the background to help their kids with more than basic material.  It's not that uncommon for parents to be completely baffled by their kids' math homework - and that's even at the grade school level.  On a humourous note, one of my colleagues was complaining about this very thing.  His oldest was in grade 7 and, while he could help the kids with his homework (he's a qualified actuary with a degree in math) he said that other parents were complaining but the school wouldn't do anything.  So three of us sat down with one of the questions from his son's homework and decided to construct the most ridiculous solution we could come up with.  Given that the three of us had six math degrees among us (including a PhD and two MSc's) and six actuarial designations we were having fun.

Density!Density! I live in the University area, slightly outside of the hub of student housing. What in many communities is one of the nicest neighborhoods has, largely, been despoiled in ours, over the years. How? The infamous mother-in-law home built in the garden behind the main home. How many mothers-in-law actually live in one? I've never even heard of one. These are used as income boosters for the homeowner. Yes, higher density is achieved, but in so doing, the peace and tranquility of neighboring families that wish to enjoy their gardens for the tranquil customary retreats such spaces originally are designed for--- is lost. Destroying family neighborhoods isn't a smart policy. Eugene has plenty of room for vertical development; it's more ecologically sound and it doesn't ruin families' small private greenspace.

Actually, aboriginals were for the most part, equal partners with the fur traders. More or less. There were some nuances. In trying to show that history is a minefield, you've yourself stepped on a mine in the minefield that is history.

There was no annexation of Crimea. The claim otherwise is more fake news, meant to hype people up into supporting a position that isn't grounded in reality, but stems from ulterior motives. Crimea's democratically-elected government organized a referendum to rejoin Russia (as they'd been trying to do for over 25 years). After the referendum was successful, Crimea's government applied for accession to Russia. Crimea was an unbound region at that time, not a part of Ukraine, as Ukraine had ceased to exist as a legal or constitutional entity when its constitution was rendered null and void in February 2014 - meaning, there were no Ukrainian laws, and no Ukrainian territory. The outcome of the Crimea referendum has been confirmed as authentic by over a half-dozen international pollsters, and Crimea has invited the UN to visit and witness the situation. Linux Mint or Manjaro or Ubuntu are very easy to install, even for non-techie types.  They have what is essentially an automatic installer that does it all for you.  You can download and run a live USB so you can try it first without disturbing anything on your system.  If you like it you have a choice of installing and obliterating the existing OS or installing side by side (dual boot).  There are about two dozen different versions of Linux (all free) but the ones I mentioned above seem to be the most widely used and have the largest online support communities of users (linuxquestions.org is a superb support source).  If there are some apps you use and need that don't have a Linux version, there's an interface app  called WINE that will run Win apps on Linux.

katarina13: There are even more mundane and commonplace illustrations of the widespread effects of declining living standards facing many Canadians. I was talking to a neighbour, a senior in his 70s, who the other day told me he's had his teeth removed and replaced with dentures because he couldn't afford the cost of maintaining his original teeth. When he was covered by workplace benefits he had access to affordable dental care but had to significantly reduce this care after retiring. As he told me, the removal of his teeth was simply a financial consideration. All the money that went into dental care over several decades was essentially wiped away because this province (Ontario) and country can't or won't set up an affordable system to ensure that its seniors get such care. Ordinary people who've worked and paid taxes throughout their adult lives are on their own to meet the rising costs of necessities, including housing and (increasingly) health and dental care.

Both the CPI-U and the PCEPI are dysfunctional inflation indicators for an inflation targeting central bank since they exclude housing prices. Housing price inflation seems to have faltered recently but the annual inflation rate is still much stronger than the PCEPI or CPI inflation rate. The national Case-Shiller HPI inflation rate for May was 5.6%, with Zillow Real Estate Research forecasting 5.3% for June. The US Fed has not given any indication that it actually targets a 2% inflation rate. From January 2012 forward, the average annualized inflation rate has been just under 1.2%. It was a mistake to choose such a high target as 2% in the first place, especially given that the PCEPI‚Äôs chain Fisher formula means it virtually eliminates upper level substitution bias to be found in other inflation measures like the CP-U.

Unfortunately, the author really doesn't suggest any solutions which I anticipated since near the beginning he said he was issuing a challenge to the system.  It was an informative article but really doesn't add anything new to the discussion.  The fact is that benefits for PERS Tier 1 beneficiaries are going to handicap this state in the provision of services for the next thirty to forty years.  PERS will continue to dominate all of our public discussions about state finances.  The Supreme Court of Oregon has upheld the contractual rights of beneficiaries to receive the benefits they were promised regardless of the implications.  All public monies must first be applied towards the obligation to these beneficiaries.   When a public body establishes a budget the costs for PERS contributions come right off the top.  Then the agency figures out how to make do with what is left.  Usually that means cuts in services.  The hands of our leaders are largely tied when it comes to this issue.

Here's the problem with that: The Attorney General is supposed to be a non-political office, more akin to a law enforcement position, and the AG should behave more like an independent judge than a legislator. In fact, the law preserves his independence and protects him from political influence by preventing the governor from unilaterally firing him. The problem, then, is that once an AG starts making noise about running for office, he raises questions about the true motives behind his decisions. Is he doing this to curry favor? To appeal to future contributors? For the good press? Or is it really in the best interests of the state? Most importantly, is he misusing his legally-protected independence? If Doug Chin is thinking about running, he should resign and avoid any potential cloud on the office.

Rains arrival almost always puts out the big persistent forest fires as it has for millennia.  The extinguishing rain highlights the wastefulness of the hundreds of millions of dollars spent annually on the firefighting air force. The use of enormously expensive helicopters and tankers does little to quench big blazes other than provide media fodder. The money would be better spent on the ground troops who ignite the back burns and clear the fuels. I say this having fought fire and worked on preventive fuel reduction projects.  By ""preventive fuel reduction projects"" I don't mean logging. I refer to clearing small understory trees, slash, brush, and grasses down to bare soil beneath the forest canopy. Especially around house perimeters, property lines, and on both sides of forest roads. Creating and maintaining this condition is what helped save my cabin in the midst of the Biscuit Fire.  After spending over $30,000,000 to mostly watch Biscuit burn, it was the rain that put it out!

The analogy to Kosovo isn't the right one for a couple of reasons  1) even though Kosovo  was deemed illegal because it was action taken outside of UNSC sanction  there was relatively broad consensus among the allies  in support of the action taken. In fact NATO assets and allied aircraft were deployed multiple times to target Serbia forces. This multilateralism  gave the bombing  an element of legitimacy which the current attack does not.  In the Syria case - Trump informed US allies but did not seek out their support or try to achieve consensus. Really a full blown unilateral action.  2) The Kosovo bombing campaign  was in lieu of a ground war which Wesley Clark then SACEUR preferred. But more importantly it had a specific purpose - not to punish but to eliminate the threat Serbia forces posed to the Kosovars (even if faked).  In the Syria case Trump's only purpose appears to be to punish and deter. But in terms of eliminating Assad's capability a ground war is necessary.

Hmm.  Thirty-five years ago, in a case known as Seneca College v. Bhadauria, the Supreme Court of Canada ruled that one can't sue in court based on a breach of the Human Rights Code.  Since then, the appropriate forum (for a non-union employee) is to use Human Rights Tribunals.  To the best of my knowledge, class action law suits based solely on Human Rights violations don't escape this ruling.  The Ontario Human Rights Code allows a limited right to sue, depending on whether there are other non-civil rights claims in the suit.  I'm not aware that the Canadian Human Rights Act has a similar provision.

The Bank of England currently uses the UK CPI (which is also the UK HICP) as its target inflation indicator. It is quite inappropriate for that purpose as it excludes house prices. For the moment probably the best monthly indicator for central bank purposes would be the RPI for all items excluding mortgage interest and council tax with an adjustment for the formula effect. This index could be better, as it omits stamp duty, which would undoubtedly have pulled the annual inflation rate higher over recent months. Nevertheless, it shows an annual inflation rate of 3.4% in August 2017, up from 3.2% in July.

Getting rid of a way to truncate long reply threads seems like it might cause other problems. Something like this:  1. I'm the most popular comment! a. response b. response c. response d. response e. response f. response g. response h. response i. response J. response 2. Perhaps seeing the four most popular responses to each comment could be done? I'm not sure.

Sorry, I didn't realize I was hogging the access to Google. Lee and Jackson were childhood heroes of J. Henry Ferguson, owner of the Colonial Trust Company, who left money in his will for the statue. A shortage of materials for the sculptor during wartime caused a decade's delay in its dedication. On hand that day in 1948 among 3,000 Baltimoreans were the generals' grandchildren, the governor and the mayor, Thomas D'Alesandro Jr., who brought along his 8-year-old daughter. You may know her today as Nancy Pelosi. The statue was placed in a park across the street from the Baltimore Museum of Art and Johns Hopkins University. Baltimore was below the Mason-Dixon line, but Maryland, a war-torn slave state, never seceded from the Union. (John Wilkes Booth was from Maryland.) A retirement home near Baltimore for Confederate soldiers closed in 1932. The Union Soldiers and Sailors statue, Baltimore's lone monument to the victorious, is the only one the city paid for and endorsed.

Believer:  As Sandia says, she (Jennifer) is NOT doing the ""technical and fundamental analysis"". She is going to lists that a computer provides where a screen has been run -- a screen that, perhaps, looked at the Relative Strength Index (RSI) of a number of stocks. My broker's on-line system allows me to check the RSI of stocks, as does Stockcharts.com (and likely others) -- looking for stocks with RSI values of 30 and below as well as RSI values of 70 and above. This, and other screens, are not definitive and the investor must judge the worthiness of a stock's RSI (in this example). Most people would not allow RSI to pick an investment. I see it as an aid in TIMING an investment -- you like the company but would you be buying it after a long run higher -- or lower?  Jennifer is not ""picking"" anything. She is generating ideas. YOU must validate their worthiness of attracting your investing dollars.

Before the internet, from the beginning of this country, we had a need to communicate in a cost effective manner.  The government created the post office and kept is relatively inexpensive.  This was part of the infrastructure, along with sewage, water supplies, roads and trains that the government regulated, paid for or subsidized.  Without this infrastructure our economic growth would have been nowhere near as 'great'.  Eventually when our (regulated) phone system (with Faxes) and some healthy competition showed up, the post office was privatized, but this did not mean all the special laws that relate to the post office went away.  Some of these are still very valuable for our infrastructure, but they do place a burden on the post office.  It is easy to forget that not everybody has internet access or can afford the higher rates of UPS or Fed Ex.

Some years ago, my combat-related PTSD hit me. This bit from Paul Simon's ""Slip-Slidin' Away"" fit:  She said, ""A good day Ain't got no pain"" She said, ""A bad day's when I lie in bed And think of things that might have been.""  One of my dogs, Belle, would lie down with me on bad days, giving me loving care. She knew I was hurting, and did her best to help. I got more help from her than from the VA shrink I saw. At that time, this man's best friend was his dog.  A year or so later, Belle got sick and had to be put down. I held her when the vet gave her the injection. I owed it to her.  Another dog, Madison, liked to get into bed with my wife and me, and have me rub her throat. When I did that, she purred. I've never known any other dog who purred. She stopped doing that after a couple of years. Madison got an aggressive cancer, and on the morning we were going to take her to the vet, she got back in bed with us and purred. She then got off, laid down and died. She was telling us ""adieu"".

In the early 1980's, The Southern Baptist Convention (SBC) did approve a non-binding resolution not to ordain women. This resolution and other resolutions from SBC  State Conventions, and other bodies are solely advisory in nature. In Baptist Tradition, the congregation is autonomous and decide by themselves the course of action how they should go forward.  The congregation decides on all aspects of policy and there isn't a higher body like the diocese or an authority like the Pope to get them to toe the line.  This is where you have read the resolution wrong looking from a lense of a top-down organization. There have been SBC Congregations that have called women as pastors and teachers.  The congregation decides also when to dismiss the pastor and make for a call for another. And the SBC National Office has no say in determining the local congregation selection as pastor.

I can remember as a kid going into the ice caves at Mt. Rainier. They were really cool! A hundred people were in there. I still have the pictures, but you can find better ones easily with an internet search. Probably in the 50's and early 60's. They were closed later due to danger, never to open again to my knowledge. I found this about them in Wikipedia.org: ""They (Paradise Ice Caves) have a varied natural history, as their size and even existence has changed over time, from a maximum surveyed length of 13.25 kilometers in 1978, to not existing at all during both the 1940s and 1990s due to glacial recession."" Back in those days if they had collapsed, it would have been a tragedy, and people would have been sad. But no one would have had to pay others money because of it, and lost their homes because of the money all have to pay in lawsuits and preparation for future lawsuits. That's a modern tragedy, and it promotes stupidity, not solves or atones for it.

Good on New Brunswick for trying to address electoral reform. I would welcome lowering the voting age - there's no evidence that younger voters are any more childish than the current electorate. Preferential ballots also make sense, though I would prefer a second round run-off election between the two candidates who polled the best in the first round. That allows you to vote with your heart in the first round and with your head in the second. One system that makes increasingly less sense in a polarizing world is proportional representation. The NDP has cited the success of that system, pointing to places and times where there was societal consensus, like Western Europe after WWII. Unfortunately, there are a host of examples of how poorly PR works in divided societies: Israel struggles to form coalitions and ends up beholden to the radical policies of tiny parties; the Netherlands struggles to maintain its half millennium tradition of tolerance, and then there was Weimar.

Its real simple: Don't oversell!  When I purchase a non-refundable airline ticket months in advance, I should reasonably expect to have a seat on the plane on the appointed day. Presumably if someone does not show up, they forfeit their airfare. How does that inconvenience the Airline?  I don't want to spend hundreds of non-refundable dollars for a seat that I MIGHT get after I have driven to the airport the night before, booked a hotel, paid for dinner, paid for longterm parking, waited 2 hours to clear security in order to fly somewhere or make a connection or take a cruise the next day. By denying me the secure knowledge that I have a seat on the flight I have booked, you potentially put thousands of my dollars at risk.  So its real simple - don't oversell. And don't qualify your apology. Make a commitment here and now that you will discontinue the practice of overselling. Its real simple. If you can't figure that out, you should resign!

The piece is at heart a pot stirrer, not a serious position.  While it does state some aspects of the discussion accurately, it is wildly off the mark on others and ignores an in place solution.  And the issue is not new, going back to the founding of Scouting.  In 1998 Scout Venturing was initiated, can and often is, coed which has the added benefit of youth learning to work together as they will find adult life - men and women in workplace and social contexts.  It serves those youth that want a different Scouting experience or one at all in the case of the girls. It also allows participation in Scouts to Age 21 vs to 18 Boy Scouts.  We had a Venture Crew associated with Boy Scout Troop 129 years ago; the same needs were true then and still are.  While the drama may make for good news filler, it's not at all valid.  Here is a link for those interested in the real story:   http://www.venturing.org/learn-more.html

Good article with some practical solutions.  When you look beyond the stereotypes and misconceptions what you really have is a sexual harassment issue in a (mostly) unionized workplace.  From the articles I've read on this story it seems like having workplace meetings in a hotel room is an accepted practice in the entertainment business. This is very uncommon in the industry I work in, and i've spent more time in hotels for work then I wish I had. Any decent hotel has a restaurant or conference rooms that are specifically set up for business meetings. There is absolutely no excuse for anyone to have a business meeting in a hotel room and the union should strictly enforce this.  Regarding the union: You are paying dues so that you can work in a safe environment. End of story. Of course we cannot go back to those times as the nature of work has changed due to technology and the family dynamic is so different after the sexual revolution. However why is that despite incredible advances in productivity and technology that the possibility of the Canadian dream seems more and more remote especially looking at the young who are now graduating to face quite often the prospect of internships instead of paying jobs. Even if we strip away the vacations to Mexico and iphones the ability for a young Canadian couple to have secure employment and a decent home becomes more and more difficult with each passing year. I do not know the answer but I wonder why.

It is difficult, I realize to talk about what ""Protestants"" believe because there are so many sects that believe contradictory things and varied things. This is what people like Bill forget when they write articles like this.  He is looking at the priesthood through the lens of his Presbyterian Faith, not realizing you cannot impute Presbyterian theology onto Catholic Sacraments.

One aspect of the NAFTA agreement that Canada, the US and Mexico could usefully revisit is the provision that allows private corporations from country A doing business (or wanting to do so) in country B to challenge before an independent tribunal the laws and administrative practices of general application in country B on the grounds that they somehow place the company doing business in country B at a disadvantage compared to companies from country B.  The rulings of such tribunals have been unpredictable and arguably overreaching.  These negotiations are an opportunity to prune back and refine the provision in question.  Doing so would also smooth the way for Canada in its ongoing negotiations with Pacific rim countries and the EU regarding free trade deals.

We Alaskans Kiss snowy Alaska winters goodbye Author: Miranda Weiss   Updated: September 28   Published January 3 HOMER ‚Äî I took last winter personally, the months of snowless dark. And I had none of my usual outlets for surviving ‚Äî or thriving ‚Äî in the cold. Local ski trails were grassy. Walking routes were glazed in ice. Without snow, I ran out of ways to coax my children outside so that we all wouldn't go crazy. I unfurled an old tarp across our steep, green backyard and sent them down it in sleds. That held their interest for 30 minutes.  I'd always bragged to folks Outside that in Alaska we enjoyed a ""reliable"" winter. But as they got buried in successive snowstorms on the Eastern Seaboard for the second year in a row, nothing seemed reliable about our winter. It wasn't winter at all. It was a punch to the gut. https://www.adn.com/we-alaskans/article/kiss-snowy-alaska-winters-goodbye/2016/01/03/

This is a classic example of scare mongering statistics. The initial study showed no significant correlations, so they went looking for all sorts of pairwise subsets. This significantly reduces the effective sample size and also increases the number of statistical tests performed. The correct response should be to increase the required significance level but this is seldom done. What was found here is almost certainly a random sampling abnormality, which is why two journals rejected it. For a thorough debunking see the Respectful Insolence blog about two weeks ago. Negative results are hard to publish and don't generate headlines, so we get to see dubious science in the mainstream press.

I'd guess you do not realize this or have forgotten it but stocks are not bonds. Bonds hav a maturity date, stocks do not. If you invest $100,000 in a five year (safe) bond, in five years you receive your $100,000 back. That is referred to as the bond maturing at par. Between now and then (over the five-year period) that bond could be worth $80,000 or $110,000, more or less. The price tha the bond trades at will fluctuate up and down with various factors that cause supply and demand to change. However, smeone who bought this bond to hold for the five-year term (and I realize how difficult that may be from a trader's point of view to understand but people actually do this---invest for the full five year term) can and likely will totally ignore these price fluctuations. After all, they are meaningless to someone with this objective of buying for the term of the bond. Regardless of what happens during the term of the bond, the destination remains the same. Paper gains/losses mean zip.

Second quote:  Ex-queen Liliuokalani confided to then Senator George Hoar (R. Mass.) that, ‚ÄúThe best thing for [Native Hawaiians] that could have happened was to belong to the United States.‚Äù  Senator Hoar wrote his own autobiography in 1903 (14 years before the ex-queen died) which included that quote.   ""Autobiography of Seventy Years"" by George Frisbie Hoar (C. Scribner's Sons, 1903).  To find that quote from Lili'uokalani, look for ""Lili'uokalani"" in the index to Hoar's book.  See also William Adam Russ, ""The Hawaiian Republic"" (1894-98) (Associated University Press, London and Toronto 1992).  On page 331, Russ quotes Senator Hoar as quoting those words of Liliuokalani.  If anyone claims that Senator Hoar was lying, or falsely quoting Liliuokalani, we should note that Senator Hoar was Liliuokalani's strongest ally in the Senate at the time the Treaty of Annexation was introduced in 1897 and the anti-annexation petition was introduced.

OK, done that, Tim. The results match what scientists are saying: human activity is impacting the climate.  You, as a geologist, should know that there have been many major extinctions in Earth's history (not human history). One of these, the Permian extinction, almost destroyed ALL life on earth. Most of these extinctions involved climate change; the Permian was probably caused by CO2 release from a supervolcano.  It is hard for us to understand that we are now numerous and pervasive enough to have a profound impact on the planet's biosphere. For most of our history we have been too few, and too poor, to have an impact. With our population now approaching the 10s of billions, the mindset that served us well for the past 800 centuries is no longer valid. We can and are impacting the environment, and our waste products are tipping the balance.  This is far too deep a subject to discuss exhaustively here. PERA's antiquated investment strategy has not helped returns. Index funds have beaten the old pension asset allocation models for many years. College endowments and more enlightened state pension funds are switching large chunks of assets to passive investments.  The projected 7.25% return, weighed down as it will be by large investments in fixed income investments, is wildly unrealistic. When providing video based evidence in court, CJIS and FIPS-140 compliance are mandatory in proving chain of custody.  It is doubtful that a $50 cell phone application over a commercial grade cell-phone network will meet those stringent standards.  Chain of custody (CoC), in legal contexts, refers to the secure chronological documentation, showing the time-stamps, custody, control, transfer, analysis, and disposition of the electronic evidence.  Public safety grade security and networking are requirement to meet that legal context.

You have a misunderstanding  of what ""independent"" means in the world of journalism and intellectual pursuit.  Have you asked the National Catholic Register why it uses ""Catholic"" even though it is independent of the Vatican?  Why not?  The ""Catholic"" states whom/what the publication is a) from, b) for, and c) about; it does not describe ownership or imprimatur. The Reporter is of and for a diverse Catholic marketplace.  The Reporter makes us think; it does not demand how we think. The Reporter guides us on our search, to be sure. But the Reporter doesn't call us ""sinful,"" ""inauthentic,"" ""nominal,"" ""so-called,"" ""lapsed,"" ""prideful,"" or ""disobedient"" if we choose other paths or other conclusions. What you imagine is simply incorrect. Modelers have no connection to temperature record maintainers. And both groups get paid regardless of their findings. And I should point out that the UHI research that I cited was part of the Berkeley Earth project (one of the preeminent surface sets) and was funded by the Koch brothers. It was established with the intent to discredit the other datasets' findings, was headed by a mild rejectionist, and included rejectionist Judy Curry as a team member. They found the same results. Oops.  The UHI paper cited contained a map of the near 40,000 stations used. While I have not seen a proportion analysis, there appears not to be a significant bias toward urban areas. And again, the findings of the UHI paper that I cited (as well as other research) indicate that urban heating has virtually no impact on global temperature records. BTW, keep in mind that they are anomalies (changes in temperature) being used for analysis, not actual temperatures.

Arkhangelsk trivia. Even hear of a Russian Blue? It's a breed of domestic short-haired cat. They are said to have originated in the Arkhangelsk region and eventually became quite popular with ships captains in this major Russian port because of their dedication to rodent hunting. They don't mind getting cold or wet doing their thing. Eventually English ships carried them to England and they did get to see the Queen and she (Queen Victoria) kept a few for the palace. They are really gray but when the sun hits them just right you would swear they are blue. I have one and it is a true Arctic Cat. Believe it or not.

I had thought that way once, before my son joined a fraternity. He was enrolled at Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology where 36% of the students do belong to fraternities. The college regulates the fraternities including careful control of the pledging. The fraternities, which are on campus,  are very involved in the college activities and provide a significant amount of the housing on campus. Though I feel that my son might have been more successful academically if he hadn't tried to depend so much on the help of his frat brothers with his classes. On the other hand, his frat brothers still, seven years later, provide friendship, support, and professional networking. Perhaps more universities need to look at a model, such as Rose-Hulman, and see that fraternities can be controlled and do not need to be allowed to run amok with such serious consequences. Part of it is that Rose-Hulman, ranked as one of the top engineering schools in the country, puts academics as its highest priority.

Many fossil-fuel companies have branched out into renewables. Why?  - There's lots of government money flying around that they can vacuum up. - They are hedging their bets in case the green revolution really does happen (not likely IMO). - It's good PR and makes them appear forward-thinking to people who haven't studied the issues very hard.  But most importantly, renewables are intermittent sources of power. They need standby capacity that can kick in quickly when the wind/sun/etc dies off. The more renewable power, the more standby capacity is needed. And the crucial fact is, standby power sources tend to be fossil fuels: gas, oil and coal (where permitted) ‚Äî since they have the easiest time adjusting output.  So it's not hard to see why fossil fuel interests might support renewables, knowing their business is guaranteed right up until renewables can completely replace all other sources of power (i.e., never).

It‚Äôs an interesting article but is biased in that it fails to point out the drawbacks of wind power - mainly that it is not a reliable source (since wind is not constant) and that it has a high cost of both implementation and maintenance as well as a short infrastructure life and that it is not without it‚Äôs own environmental impact. Its possible that wind farms are becoming economically competitive in the UK which has one of the highest costs of electricity in the world. If we accept that (in doing so we ignore the UK‚Äôs massive government subsidies of the industry) it does not mean that they will be competitive in Canada in a country where electricity costs are a fraction of the UK costs. Canadians are not prepared to triple their electricity price in order to move away from Hydro which is the cheapest, cleanest and least environmentally damaging source in the world. The article presents an inaccurate picture of the potential of wind energy in Canada which is quite limited.

No, a reduction to 35 mph likely won't help much. The relationship between death and life relative to the speed of the car that strikes someone is a very steep curve from 20 mph to 30 mph. Over 30 mph, almost everyone dies; below 20 mph, almost everyone lives. A speed reduction actually aimed at saving pedestrian lives would have reduced the speed limit to 25 mph. In an ODOT world, where roadway deaths are up something like 40% over the past two years (yes, that's higher than the miles driven were up and much higher than the national numbers were up), safety always takes a back seat to speed.  Realistically, the only way to reduce deaths in that corridor is to lower the speed much more, probably by reducing the number and width of lanes. In this sedentary culture, that's not likely to happen. We'd rather die and kill than have safe transportation infrastructure, and that's too bad.

Sounds nice, but I wonder if a ""bricks and mortar"" style of gallery, rather than an exclusively online exhibit, is really a good idea in this day and age. I suspect that most visitors, especially younger ones, would spend most of their time taking photos of the photos and then looking at them later on their cell phones. I like public spaces and galleries, but I find that I am increasingly enjoying the experience of looking at old photos of Canada that I can access online through various facebook history groups and other sites. And with my large monitor, I can often get closer to the details of the photo that i would be able to in a public gallery. Why not scrap the idea of a physical gallery and simply put the resources into the online version, and have a physical archive so that the actual photos are protected for posterity?

This is a solid message - ""Don't replace physicians; instead, augment the team.""  As Mary Ann commented here, dietary education is a very appropriate role for NPs in the healthcare team at the VA. Far from trying to ""protect their turf,"" as NPs enjoy saying about doctors (without any evidence back that claim), physicians have actually been silently trying to ""clean up the mess"" made of our veterans' medical care by primary NPs as those veterans eventually come across our path in the current system. Re IBM Shares, I'm a bit puzzled by the math on the U.S. withholding tax. If the shares are in a registered retirement plan there is no withholding. If they are held in a non-reg account (and it looks as though that's the case) then, yes, there is 15% withholding but it's a moot point since someone with income of $75k would recover it all via the Foreign Tax Credit.  To my mind, the only area where the U.S. withholding tax comes into play is for U.S. dividend paying stocks held in a non-retirement registered plan - TFSA, RESP or RDSP. There the withholding tax is not recoverable.  But even there, depending upon one's investment goals and risk tolerance, it can make sense to hold U.S. dividend paying stocks - for example, i hold two in my TFSA.

It's about time. The practice of dumping and reloading at the transfer station in Glenwood has been archaic for years. Yes, trash haulers will drive more, but the increase is marginal at best, and wait times at Short Mountain will be no longer, and more likely much less, than at Glenwood. This will also transfer the cost of trash hauling to the user, rather than the general taxpayer. It will, to a small extent, reduce the amount of time load on city streets, with a somewhat minimal reduction in additional road damage caused by the heavy axle loads of full trash vehicles. Finally, it will permit the County to sell or redevelop that large Glenwood transfer station, which will have both tax and economic development benefits to the county and both cities. No, it won't reduce taxes, but keep in mind the County has been unable to fund many services because of budget issues. The question is how will this better enable them to meet citizens needs.

If you live outside Seattle and you do not want a heroin injection site in your city, the county ordinance is your only saving grace. Repealing it will make it possible for the Seattle King County Public Health Department to site it anywhere they please. The judge's ruling on I-27 provides us insight. In a public health emergency, the public health  officer through the Public Health Board has incredible power. Please remember the Tylenol tampering case (removed a product from drug store shelves) and Jack in the Box e-coli  (shut down businesses). The county ordinance, thanks to Councilmember Balducci provides an opt out for communities. Simply put, the county won't site in your city if you opt out. Remove that protection through passage of I-27 and the public health officer can site it wherever they want. I-27 was crafted by the Republican Party based on polling so it could be used as a wedge issue. The irony is passing I-27 removes the one obstacle to siting an injection site here.

Your paean of praise for the CBC as the only news reporting source in the country without stakeholders is hilarious.  Actually, the CBC is more stakeholder driven than all other news outlets because its entire workforce are stakeholders.  Slant CBC's coverage toward the Liberals and be pandered to with major increases in subsidies (e.g. Trudeau outbid everyone in 2015 with a $175 million increase over five years) and handsome pay, perk and pension increases to an already exorbitantly compensated unionized CBC workforce.  Slant CBC's coverage toward the Conservatives and, at best, expect freezes in subsidies and employee compensation and, at worst, a reduced role and mandate and cuts in subsidies and in employee compensation and numbers.  The CBC staff is not for sale but they are sure for rent. The US Constitution grants Presidents broad power to hire and fire FBI directors, but Federal Law still applies and can be at the same time violated under certain fact patterns, specifically for obstructing justice, and for the same action of the President firing his FBI director. Thus, while a President has the Constitutional right to fire an FBI Director, he may, under certain circumstances, be obstructing justice in so doing. I'm not saying that this is or isn't the case here; just that this point is overlooked in this article. Also, what civil liberties are at risk for protecting the people from Presidents obstructing justice? None. It protects the integrity of the Democratic system and provides a slight disincentive to Presidents who might be inclined to give into such obstructionist behavior. There's a lot of Constitutional leeway there for sure, but it's not limitless. I believe that Trump's intent was to obstruct, but he out-clevered federal law using carefully vague language.

Two out of three of the proposals make good sense.  The US exists in a competitive world, and our tax system needs to take that into account.  Multinational corporations, whether the parent company is based in the US or abroad, make decisions all the time about where to put the next manufacturing plant, research center or headquarters.  The US's current corporate tax rate of 35% puts the US economy at a serious disadvantage when almost all our trading partners have rates of 15% to 20%.  Get the jobs and wealth here!  Lower the corporate rate substantially  --- whether 15% or 20%.  Find sensible ways to raise revenues with other taxes, such as energy or financial transaction taxes, VAT, border adjustment taxes, changes to individual rates.  Profits held overseas produce no tax revenue.  Charge a much lower rate and bring the money home.  This will produce substantial one-time tax revenues and bring more wealth into the US.  Full expensing of capital investments makes no sense.

The president and vice president do not write laws.  The president can sign bills into law, or he can veto bills.  The Controlled Substances Act was signed into law in 1970 by Richard Nixon.  Yes, Nixon was a Republican, but in 1970 the House and Senate were both controlled by Democrats.  Since 1970, Republicans have controlled the White House for 26 years while the Democrats have controlled it 20 years.  No changes to the Act, but again, presidents do not write bills, Congress writes bills.  Since 1970, the Democrats have controlled the House 30 years while the Republicans have controlled it 18 years.  The Democrats have controlled the Senate 30 years while the Republicans have controlled it 18 years.  This is where the bill should have been introduced.  Did anyone introduce legislation to do so?

Here is my guess and I will be the first to say that, like all of us here, we are assuming a lot.  People seem to think there is an easy black market for weapons and I just don't think that's the case. I see a constant argument that criminals are just buying the guns illegally, and gun restrictions won't keep guns out of the hands of criminals. And while that may be the case in small pockets I disagree.  To me, I think there are 4 easier explanations.  1 A seemingly normal, law-abiding citizen buys a gun and then, seemingly unpredictably uses it in a crime.  2 A person buys guns legally, commits a crime in which they would be prohibited from possessing a gun, keeps the gun through a number of different oversights and then uses the gun in a future crime.  3 A person who is prohibited from possessing a gun takes or is given a gun be an acquaintance who, otherwise, is a normal gun owner.  4 A person who should be prohibited from possessing a gun is able to buy one due to oversights.

Ok, here. Cheyenne Mountain Resort is a private business. Its not a college campus or a public park or a random field in the middle of nowhere. What you are suggesting, from what I can understand, is you want to make political beliefs ""protected"" the same way things like gender/race/sexual orientation are, in that businesses should not be allowed to turn down their services based on that alone. I disagree - as sometimes, some views (like those of people who believe in genocide or a superior race) are so bad, that a business even slightly associating with them, could crush their business. As an avid cyclist I have to laugh at the idea of bike lanes in Canada.  In winter their use is almost zero, while 99% of the rest of the time any particular spot in them is empty. JJ, horses are not ""mechanical transport,"" that's why they are allowed on trails in some Wilderness Areas.  And every time someone complains about horses in Wilderness Areas, I just shake my head.  Take a look around, if you are worried about a user group losing trail access, that would be horse riders not mountain bikers.  Plus, horse riders are such a small user group.  It is estimated that horseback riders are 10 times smaller than mountain bikers.  Mountain bikers are around 2.8% of the population where horseback riders are around .24% of the population.  And you write ""9 times out of 10 this is about a user group (hikers) not wanting to share space, nothing more. It's a ""we were here first"" thing""   That's totally incorrect.  I'd say the thing hikers want is to hike in peace.  The amount of trails that are hiker only is dwindling every day.   The Forest Service says that mountain bikers can ride on 78% of their trails, that means hikers can only have peace on 22% of the trails.

Employer provided drug benefits are critical to the health of millions of Canadians contributing over $10 billion in 2014 according to the Canadian Life and Health Insurance Association. Private benefit plans have helped offset the cost of public programs and serve other employer purposes, such as keeping employees and their dependents well and at work. Increasing business taxes for health and dental benefits will only serve to reduce employers' ability to continue coverage due escalating drug cost from expensive specialty drugs such as biologics. The insurance industry is unlikely to continue to provide risk protection for annually recurrent high cost drugs as incidence and expense increase with new medications. Provincial drug plans are also at a tipping point as cost thresholds are exceeded. I appreciate Steve Heimel's thoughtful letter.  The Confederate flag rouses no warm feelings in me; not because of slavery, but because the people who had it plastered on their trucks when I lived in Virginia decades ago were trash, always armed and often drunk.  They gave me trouble a few times when I was quietly, legally fishing rural trout streams.  But the after-history of the Civil War is one of America's historical treasures.  No reprisals, no prolonged exclusion of the Confederate states from full resumption of political rights.  Slavery was ended and Negroes made citizens.  Reconstruction forced the participation of Negroes in Southern political life--often successfully--until they were excluded from it by abusive laws after Reconstruction ended.  The chapter that followed--over a century of segregation and black oppression--was a political failure of the whole nation.  But it was not some kind of extension of slavery; the Civil War survivors had little to do with it.

They can draw loaded guns, and it sometimes doesn't even amount to an arrest, much less an assault.  Law enforcement officers also have to protect themselves.  In this case, there were three people, with six hands that could have done almost anything, at an abandoned tank farm.  The VPSO had to protect himself.  In New York City, all three people would have been face down on the ground.  If any of them tried to get up, he would know he could be shot, without the police saying a word.  The VSPO here gave a verbal warning.  While excessive force should be against the law, I don't see that here.  Moreover, the charges here could have a chilling effect on VPSOs from protecting their villages by performing their duties and protecting themselves.  The article suggests that taking photos was improper.  To the contrary, police should be required to video and audio record their investigations.

Concurrent with the NOAA cuts, the Administration repealed the notification requirement placed upon chemical manufacturers as to the dangerous substances they produce on their sites. As a result, first responders to Houston's Harvey lacked that crucial information when arriving at plants and factories awash with floodwater and likely were unknowingly exposed to air and water borne toxins. The impetus for the repeal was under the guise of elimination of imposition of government intrusion into private enterprise but when it comes to matters of public health and safety, such oversight should be mandatory, not optional and not be secondary to the pursuit of profit. On the anniversary of 9/11, it's entirely hypocritical to laud the noble and brave efforts of our emergency personnel while undermining the base protections which enable them to safely execute their duties.

I was once opposed to the concept of lot splitting, for similar reasons as some Edmonton residents express here.  But the City of Richmond BC, under pressure from developers, allowed new houses to be built almost to the side lot line,  and also allowed for massive set-backs.  These setbacks are popular for three car garages, and the City allows almost the entire front yard to be paved.  Now new build  homes dominate the lot.  The zoning for the property neighbouring us is  almost 5000 sq feet. It will sell for three million upwards. This is typical in the neighbourhood.  When completed, the house may be occupied for only part of the year, or not at all.  It is guaranteed to be under-occupied for the five bedrooms.  Far better that two homes be built.  There would be no difference to set-back or how far away the houses are to property lines.  In insisting that lots not be subdividable, Edmonton neighbourhoods should be careful what they wish for.

Addiction really is a disease, and without outside intervention alcoholism can travel for many generations. I speak from experience, having grown up in an alcoholic family, and having watched the misery that struggle created. At a minimum, if indeed this isn't a one time thing, stress related, the kids need to be protected. It isn't a personal failure, or a personal choice, at least my mother's alcoholism wasn't controllable. She crashed several cars, messed up several kids, and finally killed herself. Finally, my father just let her drink, unable to fix things, and sitting at a dinner table with her drunk was absolute agony.  Recovery is the biggest word in the English language. Any culture that is too small to provide significant recovery services to suffering people is as to blame as anyone. No one who reads this article need feel shame, as shame is one of the causes of the disease. But when kids are involved the struggle is life or death. Hugh Massengill, Eugene Oregon

Why are they ""supposed to be"" that way?  When I was a kid, a foreign language was an elective first offered in high school.  And at least 90% of kids who took them left high school unable to have a real conversation in the language.  When introduced younger, language classes have much better results.  And immersion programs in elementary school result in bilingualism and billiteracy.  Of course, it has to be used or it will slowly fade.  Why should we do what we did 20 years ago if it didn't work?  And, what American kids are being hurt here?  English learners?  I also wonder if we're talking about the same thing.  I know at one point there was allegedly a program where the teacher would say something, translate it, say something else, translate.  That's not what dual programs are.  One language is spoken hours at a time.  Also, they're predominantly elementary school programs.  If a kid enters the school system at 16 speaking no English, that's hard, needs a different approach.

My wife retired as a full-time nursing professor a couple of years ago and her position is now being staffed by several part-timers. The colleges need experienced full-time staff for the majority of the program delivery and continuity to ensure quality. The reality is that instead these colleges have loaded up management administrators at the expense of front-line teaching staff. The number of these managers has nearly DOUBLED over the past 16 years while the number of faculty members has decreased relative to the number of students in the same period.  I estimate that the college system could save approximately $200 million annually just by going back to the 2001 ratio of managers to students. What other organizations have doubled their management staff ratio? It's ridiculous.

It will be interesting to see with this advisory committee comes up with its recommendations to increase economic growth. Presumably, they will have consodered ered the thesis of Robert Gordon's  highly regarded book ""The Rise and Fall of American Growth: the US Standard of Living Since the Civil War"", viz. that we are in an era of slow growth in which investing in innovation will not  generate as much growth as it has in the past.  When it comes to economic growth and unemployment there are four elephants in the room: automation, free-trade, offshoring and slow growth. All of these are daunting forces and I have a lot of sympathy for governments who will try create jobs in the face of them.  Let's hope the 20 recommendations of this advisory committee  take account of these forces.

I am a new owner of a used Leaf - a carefully made decision based on the practical considerations of *my* circumstances and observations of the multi-year experiences of electric car owners I know. The only issue to resolve has been the sense of fear that I will forget, or be unable to charge the car, or be able to charge it quickly enough. I have come to realize that, for me, this fear has no more reality than the fear of having a monster under my bed. That is, only in my head. Otherwise in every respect the car is an improvement over every car I have ever owned: Quiet, stable, solid, comfortable, agile. In 2017 dollars, I've spent $200,000+ on car purchases & repairs over the last 45 years (not counting fuel). This would easily have been halved if all of them could have been electric. Leaves more than enough $ left over to mitigate the risk of replacing a battery pack with a real life fractional % failure rate.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot at stake. West Coast fisheries are economic drivers of many coastal communities, and the seafood we enjoy depends on a food web that is likely to be affected by more corrosive water.‚Äù I'm not 100% sure which member of the panel is being quoted but they have it wrong. So-called Ocean Acidification (which does not make the ocean acid), does not make the ocean water corrosive. The Panel appears to have only one physical chemist and I don't think that he could be called a chemical engineer. I should say that my field of engineering is electronics but I do understand the Calcium saturation of water -- the Langelier saturation index [LSI]. The ocean at shallow depths is always saturated with Calcium no matter what the pH or how much Carbon Dioxide it has in it (LSI=0). It becomes corrosive when it is not saturated with Calcium (LSI<0), It is the water that upwells from the depths which is not saturated that is corrosive.

We had 3,000 tourists in 1900.  In 2000, we had 7 million.  In 2016, Hawai‚Äòi had almost 9 million tourists visit our islands. When is enough enough?  Former Gov. George Ariyoshi said in 2004 ‚ÄúWhat deeply concerned me as governor continues to concern me these many years later: The travel industry is in danger of degrading and eventually destroying the scenic and cultural resources on which it has thrived, and hardly anyone seems to be talking about this dire possibility. Visitor numbers are up, and that seems to be all-important. ‚Ä¶ The reason is that the No. 1 item on the public agenda should be carrying capacity. How much tourism can Hawaii comfortably take? When do we have too much of a good thing? At what point do a large number of our citizens rebel against the level of visitor intrusion? At what point do visitors sense this and start to pull away? Climate scientists know about the Ice Ages.  I promise you.  Assertions about anthropomorphic climate change are in no way predicated on the notion that the climate was static before the appearance of humans on the scene.  I don't know why you would even think that they are.  Also, we have global temperature records going back 2 million years (https://www.nature.com/news/longest-historic-temperature-record-stretches-back-2-million-years-1.20673), so your implicit claim that climate scientists are considering only the past 100 years is just wrong.  Furthermore, we have a pretty good idea of what climatic conditions constitute a habitable environment for humans.  So the idea that extreme climatic conditions in the planet's pre-human history make the prospect of those conditions returning somehow okay is . . . curious.  No one is saying that natural climate variability does not exist, but only the willfully ignorant say that humans are not accelerating dangerous climate changes.

Getting absorbed into a discussion about the causes of the hurricanes -- something that can be neither proved nor disproved at this point -- is a distraction from the real justice issue at hand, which is that disasters like these are hardest on those who have the least to begin with.  It's the inner-city poor in this country and those living on the margins in undeveloped nations like the Dominican Republic that are hit hardest and have the longest recovery when such events happen. It's not just poverty that is the issue, but the systems we all support (knowingly and unknowingly) that perpetuate poverty.  The coldest, hardest truth for Christians to own is that others pay a price for our comfort. Climate science may well prove to have a role in these disasters, but the science I'm most concerned about at the moment is the science of economics.

DennisM, Thank you.  And yes, you caught the main point I was trying to make: the concept that a consensus can (usually) be developed, even if not everybody is in full agreement.  The important part is exactly as you described: church being a relationship, a space where we can hear, listen, and contribute.  We won't always agree, but the goal will be to understand.  The key is the process by which that happens.  That process may well be what ""being church"" is really all about.  It's the ongoing struggle, the consistent desire to find the best solution we can, learning from our mistakes, and in the process, building a trust in each other.  To get that ""best solution"" will require that voices not be excluded, simply because of a person's gender, wealth or poverty, or status in the church.  The institution faces serious problems as the effects of the drop in vocations rolls through the system.  The problem can best be addressed by listening to all of those voices.  But will the bishops?

I sympathize with your PR problem. All trawling techniques have huge bycatch mortality - shrimping, for example kills 4.5 non-target species for every shrimp harvested.  Additionally, bottom dragging destroys the very habitat needed to produce the target species.  Trawling is a cheaper way to harvest certain species, but your economic success comes at the expense of others.  Most Alaska readers know that their sport and commercial harvests are significantly reduced by salmon and halibut killed in your nets and then thrown overboard to feed the birds.  We are not sympathetic to your opposition to more targeted techniques, such as pots, which would virtually eliminate salmon and halibut bycatch - but lower your profit margin.  We can agree on one thing - we shouldn't increase trawling opportunities to foreign flagged boats.  We disagree that crying JOBS! is an excuse to continue a destructive and inefficient fishery.

We entrusted you to do the right thing, but you failed spectacularly.

Many reasons. Tepees, in order to be warm and weather-proof, require animal skins: loads of animals roaming in herds AND the right to toodle around vast swathes of land hunting said animals -- neither of which requirements currently survives. Instead, the vast swathes of land were claimed by the Crown, and FN were herded onto reserves, their traditional practices outlawed, and their children taken away to receive an education that was intentionally shaped to un-FN them with contempt for, among other things, tepees. Plus, the reason for tepees is that if you find you're living in a place with unpotable water or not enough food or fuel, you can pick it up and move to a better spot. Moving is no longer allowed, and reserves were lands that no one else wanted, bad soil, whatever. On top of that, natural water sources were limited -- and on many reserves now have been catastrophically polluted by industry. In other words, we took away all the reasons tepees were good.

If the philosophical doctrine of determinism is discounted while the non-omnipotence of the person is accepted, then what is reasonably left but an interdependent model of creation that is beyond the overall control by any constituent part (and, therefore,  open to the influence of the unknown variable, chance). Given the two premises above, there is no other logical conclusion.  Weather is never predictable, which is why meteorologists refer to forecasts, not predictions. There is always the influence of that unknown variable which disallows such certainty.  For the Christian, this is actually good news: the humble acceptance of vulnerability through non-omnipotence is an occasion for surrendering self to the divine will. When this is done, the role of chance in life is reduced, if not eliminated altogether.

The notion of a republic is that representatives can make wiser decisions than the masses as a whole and this indeed makes great sense since representatives presumably are selected by the people for their experience, knowledge, and wisdom.  Legislation to ensure that the Presidential vote is a purely popular one is not necessarily in the country's best interest.

The federal debt is simply the total amount of money that the federal government has spent into the economy.  As the monopoly issuer of the US dollar, the federal government can hypothetically create and spend as much new money into the economy as it wants to.  As a monetarily sovereign nation, the US can never go broke unlike a private household, business, state or local government  or even a nation like Greece which gave up its monetary sovereignty when it joined the EU.  Furthermore, the federal government doesn't need to tax its citizens or borrow money from a nation like China to fund spending.  The debt ceiling is an arbitrary number imposed by Congress that acts as an unnecessary constraint to federal spending.  The only natural constraint to federal spending is inflation which is a result of a shortage in supply of a finite resource such as oil, food, cars or people (workers).   Our federal taxes keep inflation under control by removing excess dollars from the economy.

WSF is one of the safest ferry systems in the world.  I disagree with Mr. McKnights's letter regarding lifejackets on the ferries. I think other ferries, CG vessels and local citizens could safely remove all passengers in in emergency.  I don't think a crew member would be nervous if you wore a lifejacket on board a ferry.  They might shake their head in disbelief though.  If  Mr. McKnight is so fearful of riding a ferry, maybe he should drive around the next time he has to go to Seattle. Two copies of the gene = cystic fibrosis.  It's not all upside when it comes to ""fixing genetics"".   And yet, what you will hear from those who stand to make money is that it is all upside. Again, you are wrong.  The Wells are located over 10 feet from power lines.  The mast on a service truck lays over the cab and is pinned at the rear, they are over 20' long and telescope to almost double that length. This was the paraphrased wording of the actual amendment:  Proposition 13 declared property taxes were to be assessed their 1975 value and restricted annual increases of the tax to an inflation factor, not to exceed 2% per year. A reassessment of the property tax can only be made a) when the property ownership changes or b) there is construction done.  Practical experience, my folks bought a house near Santa Monica in 1972, for about 70k.  In 1978 it was probably worth about 100k, but Prop 13 valued it back in 1975, so maybe 80k.  Yes there have been tiny inflation adjustments, but their house is now worth the north side of 1.5 million.  Not sure on the exact number, but their property tax is about $2000 a year. Compare we had a house in San Diego, bought in 2006 for about 600k, our property taxes were about $6000 a year.  Great for my folks, but not fair in a macro sense.

Loans from the bank of Mom-and-Dad are basically daisy-chaining risk in real estate, especially since the down payments often come from the parents' HELOC. If this one market corrects, it's not just that junior's place is underwater, Mom and Dad won't get repaid AND their own real estate nest egg goes down in value.  Many people seem to not realize that behaviors like this contribute to unaffordability, in the same way that facilitating more borrowing or creating new buyer incentives also drive prices up. All these things help someone get into the market today and bid up prices further in the future. (I am absolutely not discounting the impact of foreign money, of course.)  If we allowed government interference in other markets the same way we manipulate (and fixate) on real estate, we would be branded communists. Mom and Dad are just making it worse. And that over-priced condo they're stretching for today won't cut it long-term and won't help junior move into a bigger place later.
