I've just had a phone conversation with the person at Ipsos who conducted the 2015 study about RT's viewership, Athanas Jamo, and they confirmed to me on the phone (and will send me email confirmation, as well) that RT's article's figures are accurate, and that 70 million people watch RT each week, and that half of them watch RT daily. So, RT receives 35 million TV viewers each day. Athanas also told me they've been contacted by many groups and people seeking to verify the results, and said they'll put me in touch with RT's director of communications for possible further details of the study, since Ipsos does not own studies once they are completed, and cannot divulge more than they have permission from the solicitors of a particular research project. The study also includes other news agencies, and Ipsos would need each's permission to release specific data about each news agency. Regardless, RT is confirmed as the world's 2nd most-watched news, after the BBC.

According to the 1897 census, 35% of Crimeans were Tatar and 33% were Russian, and Ukrainians  12%.  After Stalin's forced deportations of almost 300,000 people,Tatars were reduced to 0% in the 1959 census, while Russians made up 71% and Ukrainians 22% of the population.  Substantial Greek and Bulgarian minorities were also wiped out.  In the 1989 census, shortly before the fall of the USSR, there were only 38,365 Tatars in Crimea, compared to 1.65 million Russians and 625,000 Ukrainians.  After Ukraine became independent and welcomed the Tatars home, the Tatar population increased to 258,000.  The language issue is a non-issue, as it is in Eastern Ukraine.  I know people from Crimea who are very comfortable in either language.  And Joe Biden's son was working for a company that was going to help Ukraine develop natural gas assets off the Crimean coast which would have made it energy-independent from Russia - removing Putin's stranglehold over Ukraine as the exclusive supplier of gas

your post makes no sense economically.  Why should a person not be able to deduct their loss at 100%?  you want them to pay income tax on money they did not make?  weird.  Non residents often have very good reason to own homes in other cities - this is not a black and white issue.  And finally your worst blunder is this: city-wide increases in property values do NOT increase property taxes.  The cities use a mill rate based on municipal expenditure - you only pay your same portion of the expenditure no matter how much property values rise or fall.  The ONLY thing affecting property taxation collectively is municipal spending, period.  In fact, the explosion in construction usually means the new homes pay more taxes than the older ones, saving you money.

BIA-bilateral immunity agreements  Article 98 of the Rome Statute prohibits the ICC from requesting assistance or the surrender of a person to the ICC if to do so would require the state to ""act inconsistently"" with its obligations under international law or international agreements unless the state or the third-party state waives the immunity or grants cooperation.[31] The US has interpreted this article to mean that its citizens cannot be transferred to the ICC by any state that has signed a bilateral agreement with the US prohibiting such a transfer, even if the state is a member of the Rome Statute. The US actively pressured states to conclude such so-called Article 98 agreements, otherwise known as bilateral immunity agreements (BIAs). My husband and I live in the Ebey's Landing National Historical Reserve. Yes, aircraft fly all directions over our house, including jets, helicopters, and reconnaissance planes. However, you might see and hear 3 jets in the morning or early afternoon, and 3 in the late afternoon or evening.  For the most part, by the time you hear the jets, they're already out of sight. However, it's doubtful the noise of the jet lasts more than 60 seconds. That means if 6 jets happen to pass over our house, and conversely EBay's Reserve, it comprises 6 minutes out of the 1,440 minutes in a day or around .42% of a 24-hour period.  Chances are, if a visitor saw a Navy jet pass overhead, they'd be thrilled. They're exciting to see, especially if they're wing-in-wing. If there's a health issue, it would be minuscule.  There at dozens of noises that last significantly longer and are more damaging, such as a jack-hammer, revved up car or truck speeding down Highway 20, hum of an ultra-light, etc.

Because she sued for wrongful termination on the basis of gender discrimination (and retaliation), she apparently alleged that whatever insubordination reason the Church claimed to fire her, it was really based on the fact that she was a woman. Another example could be that she was fired for overtly complaining (perhaps to her students) that she wanted to be a priest but the Church wouldn't let her, but I can't imagine a lawyer taking such a case as a gender-discrimination claim, because a man could have made the same complaint about the Church's teaching on women priests.  Maybe she was dressing with her cleavage showing, but that's a very weak gender claim too.  If she were married and the Church fired her for being pregnant, then the ministerial exception clause is unfairly depriving her of a legitimate claim, and the Court is wrong, imo.  All speculation w/o facts.

Christianity borrows many ideas from earlier religions, such as the cult of Apollo. In some early traditions, Christ is entirely a supernatural being who never actually descends beyond the lower regions of the firmament, where he does battle with evil forces and ascends back into the upper regions, the Seventh Heaven, and so on. On the other hand, there were probably a number of actual wandering mystics in the period and scriptural Jesus could be a composite of some of them. I don't think the historicity of Jesus is ever likely to be conclusively settled, though some Biblical scholars are convinced by the rather scant mentions by Roman historians it strikes me as quite thin. As a movement, I think Rome eventually adapted to Christianity rather than the other way round. It's elevation of the low and downtrodden was a powerful subversive message in a society largely composed of slaves.

I haven't read the entire essay, but the excerpts contained in this article don't indicate he was mocking the writers OR their work, simply making his stance on 'cultural appropriation' known. While he was clearly aiming for humour with concepts like awarding a gold medal for cultural appropriation, his core message of ""explore other cultures, learn and assimilate knowledge"" is hardly divisive or mocking. It used to be what we routinely prescribed to people as the solution for racism and other 'isms'. Pointing out that even native writers struggle to bridge historical divides to accurately capture native life in previous generations, given how different their modern life is? How is that controversial?  Punishing him for making those opinions known in his essay most definitely impacts his freedom of expression.  It blows my mind that people talk about intentionally de-platforming as if it's no big deal, as if private organizations cannot censor and only the government is capable of it.

This article relies on the fallacy that introducing diversity as a recruitment priority inevitably involves ""more qualified"" applicants being passed over.  No hiring board or executive search should ever permit an unqualified candidate through.  The end result of a staffing process should be a pool of candidates, every one of whom is capable of doing the job.  At that stage leadership should be looking for the ""best fit"", at which point diversity can be one of  the criteria that an institution uses to select from among qualified candidates.  Obviously, if there are simply no women, indigenous people, or members of diversity groups that are in a qualified pool, then so be it.  But when there is a qualified person from an underrepresented group, there is no compromise on merit.

He turned once again toward the mirror, because it had to appear as though he were admiring himself in all his glory. - The chamberlains who were to carry the train held their hands just above the floor as if they were picking up the train. As they walked they pretended to hold the train high, for they could not let anyone notice that they could see nothing. - ""But he doesn't have anything on!"" said a small child. - The emperor shuddered, for he knew that they were right, but he carried himself even more proudly, and the chamberlains walked along behind carrying the train that wasn't there. -

An Emperor owned a majestic white stallion, the finest beast in all his Kingdom. One night, a thief tried to slip in and steal the horse, but was captured by the palace guards and thrown into the dungeon. The next morning, he was dragged before the Emperor's court. ""How dare you,"" bellowed the Emperor, ""lay hand on my royal steed! Jailor, put this thief to death!"" Immediately, the thief bowed deeply. ""Your judgement is peerless and wise, O Emperor,"" he calmly replied, ""but my life is of little value. I should offer you a gift before I depart. Your mount is quite a fine one, but if your eminence would spare my life for just a year and a day, I swear to you I can teach that horse to sing.  To the surprise of all, the Emperor quickly accepted the offer. The jailor whispered to the thief, ""You are a fool!"" You will be tortured when you fail. "" I am a fool?"" Much can happen in a year and a day. The King may die. The horse may die. I may die... and maybe the horse will learn how to sing.""

Feeding any wild animal is a bad idea. Sea Lions are aggressive and have little fear of humans. I have been around sea lions closely from working on commercial fishing boats. The sea lion went ballistic on deck an we all ended up in the wheelhouse with no one volunteering to go on he deck and assist the crazy animal off the deck. I was speechless watching the video when I saw how close they were to he sea lion and they took no precautions to keep their child safe as they laughed and fed the wild animal. They were lucky, if dad had not dove in and managed to get the child back on the dock the sea lion if it wanted to could have held on to his ""prey"" and easily swam off with her. I worked in the reforestation business for over 15 yrs.  I literally planted over a million trees throughout the western states. From giant sequoia in central California to larch in Montana and all the doug fir, pine and cedar in between.  Timber companies are always looking for chemical remedies to promote growth and survivability to their timber stock at the toxic cost to the environment and the reforestation workers. I remember the rashes and headaches from planting Thiram coated trees.  The nausea from the purple Garlon dripping down my leg from my ""hack and squirt' hatchet. I remember the stupidity  of having to cut down entire groves of coastal alder because they were shading a few doug firs.  I finally drew a protest line when they wanted me to thin the slow growing yew wood trees before they became a cancer drug. As our planet continues to become increasingly warmer we are going to see more pests and diseases decimate our forests.  We need to work with nature, not against.

""Monuments to Confederate soldiers were not put up to glorify slavery or any lost Confederate cause"" Yes, those monuments were. Many were put up in the early 1900s to celebrate in concrete terms the consolidation of white power. And, many Southern states incorporated the Confederate flag into their state flags during the height of the Civil Rights era, which was also the centennial of the Civil War. The addition of that Civil War symbol to state flags was an act of defiance. If a statue sits on private property, it is the right of the private property owner what to do with it. Period. If a statue is on public property, the locality in which it stands ought to hold a peaceful public debate. I think moving the statues to a central park or outside a museum would be one solution. I think all Southern state flags that incorporate the Confederate flag ought to be replaced. Also, all people have a right to peaceful demonstration. I always thought the desire for the 'highlight of the night' hits killed hockey, and ended many careers.  The large majority of those hits reflect the ethos of football, which is a game of yards.  You have to prevent forward progression down field.  Hockey is about possession, and the rule book used to reflect that.  When I played, charging was more than 3 strides into a hit.  Hammering someone into the boards was, uh, boarding.  Now penalties seem predicated on the damage inflicted. If the NHL just enforced charging and boarding, added a 'dangerous play' major for the players who choose to flatten another who has his head down,  instead of making a play for the puck, they could eliminate many of the dangerous hits.  But the NHL is a business, and as long as they insist on winning the American viewer i.e. compete with the NFL, they will not change.   The owners want those highlights, and players will remain the replaceable slabs of meat they currently are.

It reduces the risk of harm due to the accident. Wearing or not wearing a seatbelt does not alter the underlying risk or make me more prone to accident  Locking my door does not prevent a robbery. It serves to prevent a specific type of robbery - but does not prevent all robberies.  Can you point to any other situation where the device used to mitigate the risk is directly tied to or source of the risk? We don't mitigate the risk of an oil spill by spilling oil. We don't mitigate the risk of a car crash by crashing a car. Yet we encourage people to mitigate possible instances of violence, often perpetrated with guns, by carrying that same device as the mitigator?

The rail project and high-rise development have enough problems without unqualified, incompetent workers constructing projects. You get what you pay for, and in the case of construction unions, you're talking about hiring people who learned their craft in extensive training programs. Do we really want someone with dubious credentials operating a crane? Building projects downtown that brought in cheap, illegal labor ended up with numerous building code violations and, in one case, a piece of rebar fell onto a car on Bishop St.  and pierced the roof. Fortunately, nobody was hurt since it went into the unoccupied back of the car. Operating engineers, carpenters and other building trades go through years of training programs and apprenticeships to become journeymen in their fields. Foregoing the expertise and skills of these workers for cheap labor may be good for developers, but the result is unsafe, shoddy work for consumers and the public.

Floods are a normal part of the environment, and ""Climate Change"" doesn't really have anything to do with it. You can't get insurance for floods in Canada, because there is no risk involved. If you live on a flood plain, there is a 100% certainty you will be flooded. It is just a question of when. In the US they can get flood insurance, but that is because the US government subsidizes it. The taxpayer gets stuck with the costs of insuring the inevitable.  Before I bought a house in Calgary back in 1980, I read the Calgary Flood Study, issued in the 1970s shortly after the floods of the 1960s. Guess what? It predicted exactly what happened. In a 100 year flood, exactly what is predicted to happen in a 100 year flood, happens. Most people don't read flood studies, but I always do. They are very interesting. If you don't have one, you should get one.

I agree that borrowing to invest isn't the problem.  The problem is ensuring that the investment return is high enough to cover the cost of after tax interest + inflation +the fees paid.  Which for them at this current time is likely somewhere in the neighbourhood of 2%+2% + 2% = 6%.  Which could be considered their hurdle rate - anything they invest in needs to exceed 6% per year just to break even.  The more concerning point I have is the apparent lack of an exit strategy.  Swapping debt to make it tax deductible is all well and good but you still need to pay it back at some point.  Are their returns sufficient to do this and still have something to show for the added risk?

""Medicare is partially administered by outside agencies  First, other government agencies help administer the Medicare program. Private insurers obviously don't have this kind of outside or off-budget help. Medicare's administration is also tax-exempt, whereas insurers must pay state excise taxes on the premiums they charge; the tax is counted as an administrative cost"". https://www.forbes.com/sites/theapothecary/2011/06/30/the-myth-of-medicares-low-administrative-costs/#4521302c140d

Ms. Goldblatt,  I read your piece this morning and was absolutely thrilled to learn about your experiences at both the Museum of Contemporary Art and Art Institute of Chicago! I'm a budding photographer and spent an entire day shooting a series of photos at both MoCA Chicago and AIC, and have published some of my shots on Instagram. Reading your essay, while reviewing my own photos, was a great experience and I wanted to share that with you. Your commentary regarding the wall projections and feeling as if you were a ""part"" of the art, are exactly what I tried to capture in my images. I am sure ( or at least I sure hope) that many good priests struggled with what to do once confronted with the hard evidence of abuse by their peers, and the inherent conflict of reporting to their superiors, only to have the superiors sweep it under the rug, and having previously given  obedience to those superiors.  In their minds they were being faithful to the teachings of the church.  The problem inherent in a top down system is that there is no accountability for those at the top, and when those at the top abuse and misuse their authority, a crisis can and does occur.  Those at the top of the pyramid are fallible men, no different than you or I.  And quite frankly, they may believe they ARE being faithful.

As  with all normal Webfoots I'm delighted with this rain. We've been low this year and all this October rain only brought us to 29.23 inches, still 0.11 inches below normal for the  year to date..  When  German writer Theodore Kirchoff arrived in Eugene by stage in early October  1871 and stopped at the St. Charles Hotel (across Broadway from Kesey Square) he lamented that:  ""Webfoot weather overtook me there, to my annoyance.  Rain, called ""Oregon mist""¬†gave every indication of staying for a week.... ..Hardly a cheerful start to the stagecoach leg of my journey, especially as I had gotten used to sunny days and had repressed the memory of Webfoot rains.  ""People of Eugene thought otherwise.  I read it in  beaming faces: the locals were in their element.  Meekly I asked my innkeeper how long this inclemency should last.  Rubbing his hands in glee he said he expected rain for a hundred days.  A sad prospect for a traveler like me...... shut up in a stagecoach for 400 miles!""

I quit using studded tires in the 70's.  For Anchorage most of the time studs are worse or add no additional traction.  On bare dry or wet roads you will slide more with studs than with good non-studded tires.  In soft snow deep enough for no tire pavement contact they add absolutely zero value.  If I lived in a place like Valdez where there are a lot of icy warm conditions and low commute miles I might consider studded tires.  I've tested many different scenarios of winter tires over the years because I love driving year-round.  I find that a good set of stud-less winter tires with a narrow profile (while maintaining stock diameter of the tire) provides very good traction overall.  In deep snow the narrow profile cuts through the snow like ice skates providing very good directional stability.  The narrow profiles will cut into the soft snow pack instead of floating like wide tires and reach hard pack quickly for better traction. On ice they are as good as studded tires!

True, Sher, the world price of oil 'tanked' when Saudi Arabia's Oil Minister, Mr. Al-Naimi told a meeting in Houston, Texas, three years ago that the price of oil was artificially high. He said, ""Inefficient uneconomic producers will have to get out."" OPEC refused to cut production of its light sweet crude because ""Cutting low-cost production to subsidize higher cost supplies only postpones the day of reckoning."" Saudi oil is easily accessible and uses conventional processing involving boiler and distillation processes to achieve streams such as gas, NAPTHA, waxes, gasoline, kerosene, diesel, etc, and the final residual is asphalt or bitumen used for paving. Upgrading 'reverses' that process, adding heat & diluent (eg, NAPTHA) to make the sludge flow, prior to upgrading. Most world markets are not importing diluted bitumen (dilbit) for upgrading at this time. Saudi Arabia added 'renewable energy' to university engineering programs and its Energy Dept. Let's understand the processes.

Half of americans have group plans. Under the Republican plan,  group plans will continue to provide the Obamacare plan protections on things like pre-existing conditions. This is important in Hawaii, where by law, full time employees must receive and employer provided group plan. These plans are great and provide for things like prescription drug coverage and even annual glasses and optician charges for things like contact lenses. It is doubtful Hawaii will waive the Obamacare protections. However, if even one state opts out of the protections, then insurance companies can begin reducing coverage under employer group plans, including plans offered in Hawaii-- some Senators have said that they will not allow this in the Senate plan.

This is all real simple for all of you who don't know anything about it.   Survivor benefits, including health insurance survivor benefits, have always been a creature of PERS eligibility.   The issue here is that these are Tier II or III employees who can retire as early as their early 40s, but don't have PERS eligibility until they're 55.   Just for the record, a State employee who dies on duty doesn't leave his/her family destitute; the life insurance benefit is pretty lucrative.   Until an employees is PERS eligible, the only death or survivor benefit is the life insurance, and It has been that way as far back as I can remember, and that is a ways.   I actually had some authority when I was head of labor relations and I'd have just called Jake Metcalfe and made a deal to consider the deceased Troopers active employees until the spouses remarried or the dependents reached majority.   Could have done it with the stroke of my pen, and If I were nervous about it get the Leg to agree.

Thanks for the link.  I watched Fr. Scalia's talk in its entirety.  He's a very good speaker, but at some points in his logic he opts for simplicity where nuance would have put him closer to reality.  To use a metaphor, Isaac Newton's view of the world relies upon the simplifying assumptions that space and time are absolutes.  It turns out that while these assumptions make good sense in most circumstances, they don't work for your GPS devices.  You have to use Einstein's field equations for the GPS system to work.  Similarly, the Church's teaching relies on the assumption that there are only men and women.  While that is mostly true, reality is more nuanced.  To give the most dramatic example, one in 20,000 men are born looking like a woman because a particular gene is missing.  Gender is even more genetically complex, and this affects the ""orientation"" of one in every twenty-five people.  I wonder what Fr. Scalia's talk would look like if he updated his facts.

I went into town last week to do some shopping, I had a gift card for Dominos , so I decided to eat lunch there. A young man took my order, told me it would take 20-30 minutes so I took a seat and waited. This young man was for the most part, working by himself, he did have a co-worker, but he was in and out, making deliveries. I watched him work his tail off for 30+ minutes, never missing a beat, taking orders online, over the phone, as well as in person, making pizzas, sandwiches or whatever else was called for, had a kind work for his co-worker when he was there, as well as all the customers he dealt with. When he had my order ready he called me and thanked me for my patience. I thanked him and gave him $5.00, and he expressed his appreciation. I have no problem helping people like this, that work hard, don't complain and don't expect the world or the government to give them everything simply because they exist. The world needs more people like this, they are becoming a rarity

I keep wondering how best to replace ACA. It seems like the smart thing to do is offer a minimum level of Single Payer. By that, I mean, it would pay for 1) yearly physicals, 2) all vaccines (and in light of our antibiotic resistance issues, vaccines should be required), 3) General things such as general sickness (colds, flu, tonselectomy, etc), 4) General injuries such as broken bones, etc. 5) General life such as pregnancy, psych, 6) basically, the common mundane items in life, with limits set on yearly amounts.  From there, we then have medicare for old folks, and medicaid for those with less than a set amount of income. Likewise, we require that families MUST INSURE their kids, or have less than a certain income to have medicaid for them. Beyond that, let private insurance handle the more long term stuff. Then we will have to decide if we go with mandating that ppl either have private insurance, have enough money to cover their own (say multi-millionaire).

A maximum sentence of 14 years seems excessive, especially when the penalty for the same offence with alcohol is minimal. For 'mere' robbery you can get life in prison. The crucial point is, that only in the most egregious cases is the maximum sentence ever applied.  https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Canadian_Criminal_Sentencing/Appendix/Offence_Charts

Public employment tenure per se is not that difficult an obstacle to removing an incompetent employee. One has to document poor behavior and have the patience for progressive discipline. Gross misbehavior or illegal activity does not necessarily ensure speedy termination. The impediment to removing incompetent employees is finding supervisors in the chain of command with the fortitude to act on unacceptable behavior. In the lower ranks of management virtually all the supervisors are promoted from union jobs. Their hearts and minds are not necessarily attuned with accountability. Many union contracts have reversion clauses that allows supervisors to return to union jobs. Not many supervisors will offend the union on the possibility that they may become a member again But even more importantly, in public sector jobs accountability and efficiency are dim concepts. Public sector supervisory promotion is rarely correlated with improving productivity or getting rid of deadwood employees.

Not really figures, but I'll accept the prohibition of any but local, Native hunters as more-or-less substantiating in lieu of other information. It's also simply not realistic to expect folks to accept avoidable injury and death in the name of ""culture.""  And if the AK F&W and US F&W service haven't attempted to negotiate with the Native nations to establish sustainable exploitation of the resource, they're not doing the job for which they're being paid.  The allocations for commercial marine species such as halibut, salmon, geoducks and even sea cucumbers for Native use and exploitation are legally established and defined in detail.  If this isn't the case with beluga, it's tempting to conclude it's not been given priority because there's no money for white commercial interests in similarly entering into a ""partnership"" with the Native folks to manage the species.

I was up in Anchorage once staying at my sister's house when a very early morning earthquake shook the house, waking me up. Years later,  I was sitting at my computer at 4:30 am,  in Ketchikan, when I felt movement and my hanging plants began swinging above me. Now that disturbed me as we very rarely feel any quakes here despite knowing there is a fault line not too far from us and the Queen Charlotte Islands. A wonderful story of little-known Alaskan history and a self-made super intellectual individual,- & a very kind man - Neil Davis. That led to him offering me the use his motor home while in Fairbanks & enjoying many meals together followed by long evenings of discussion of many issues  over a whiskey or two at his home. Neil wrote many books, from humorous novels (The Great Alaska Zingwater Caper) to works on the Aurora, Permafrost, Healthcare in Ak, and countless articles of practical value to all Alaskans. Neil enjoyed using his new tractor/loader as he worked on his home landscape and a gold claim or two he held. Neil Davis is sorely missed by all who were fortunate enough to know him.

I just read the other day that the average windmill requires 50 metric tons of steel that can only be produced by burning huge amounts of coal.  A little over a decade ago, I spent two and a half years as a long haul truck driver while the Financial Crisis pretty much killed my livelihood as a mortgage broker.  I observed a couple of things.  Every time I drove by one of those massive wind farms, I'd try to do a quick estimate of how many of them weren't spinning on a windy day, and it was usually at least 20% of them.  The maintenance costs of those suckers are grossly under-estimated.  I also spent a lot of time driving through oil country where those ""rocking horses"" above established wells were either ""rocking"" or not.  At the time, oil prices ranged between about $120 and $90.  When prices were high, they were all rocking away, and when prices got near the lower end of the range, they were nearly all shut down.  Word to the wise: don't bet that oil prices will rise above $55.

As someone who spent 20 years commercial fishing by the Chuit (as we called it) river - I really don't get the focus on salmon as the centerpiece of this fight over mining. There aren't very many salmon there - period - and no one depends on them for much of anything. What is cool about the the Chuit is the drainage itself - a place of marvelously sized cottonwoods and estuarine serenity that is not always easy to find.  Over the last 50 years the mobile part of Anchorage has developed the west side of the inlet into a summer vacay destination - all the way from the west forelands to Knik arm. And very likely the future will see even more access - perhaps by road. The kind of experience one gets from slapping mosquitos and watching for bears in drainages like the Chuit is of enormous value to city-bound folks - and we should preserve those close opportunities.  I've got nothing against coal - BUT our legislature should find a way to make the Chuit drainage an important state park.

This is a well written article. Unfortunately, without just a bit greater specificity the statements made are easily misunderstood. For example, this information: ""dark ocean surfaces absorb the solar heat that white ice would reflect away.""    Ice reflects 80% of the sun's heat back into SPACE.   Dark water absorbs 90% of the sun's heat.    Without the real number of how much reflection is lost and how much heat is retained, the information loses something.    It is typical in our earth-destroying culture to frame things this way.  Especially when the information is coupled with news about the luxury cruise through the arctic.  It makes the loss sound far less important than it is.       I'm not expecting anything to change, but I do want to point out the open-to-interpretation framing these articles usually require. Why would we universally acknowledge something that is factually and legally incorrect?  I am an atheist but Canada unlike the US has not constitutionally entrenched the separation of church and state.  There are no clauses in our Constitution Act of 1867 and we have no counterpart of the First Amendment of the American constitution.  Our constitution actually mandates state funding of ""separate schools"" (Catholic or Protestant minorities only not other religions) in several provinces and that is constitutionally valid.  That would be anathema in the USA.  See  Adler v Ontario (AG), [1996] 3 S.C.R. 609  In fact as PM Harper correctly noted in an interview several years ago the separation of church and state is an American constitutional concept and does not apply to the Canadian constitution. He went on to say that separation of church and state in Canada has meant, traditionally, that the government will not interfere with religion.

In 2016, we published a paper on the reporting of financial conflict of interest (FCOI) relationships in Canadian clinical practice guidelines by their authors. Our results support the findings in this Globe piece.  We found that FCOI relationships between authors and drug companies are common among Canadian guidelines. We also found that it was common for authors who had FCOI relationships with drug companies to recommend as first-line treatment medications that were manufactured by those drug companies. When authors were on more than one guideline, it was also common that they disclosed different FCOI in each. Guidelines generally identified affiliations with organizations and approximately half of those organizations disclosed FCOI relationships with drug companies.  Our article is accessible here: https://bmchealthservres.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12913-016-1646-5  Adrienne Shnier, PhD York University

Looking up compensation for losses due to eminent domain, the law is clear about compensation for real property. But less so (that at least I can tell) about the value of a business. Let's say the affected businesses are compensated for costs related to moving. Where will they relocate? Will they they be compensated for loses during the move as customers obviously cannot patronize their business during the transition? What, if any, loses occur because some customers who maybe walked to the old location, will not walk to a new location that is farther away? What if the new location is not as profitable as the current one due to higher lease costs or simply the location? Do they get compensated for that? Conversely, if they are compensated for possible loses due to the above factors, what if the new location is cheaper and brings in more profit? And who pays the attorney fees to argue these merits?

Actually if you read the division of powers they are assigned exclusively to either Parliament or a provincial legislature with the exception of agriculture and immigration (s. 95).  Per section 91 "" it is hereby declared that (notwithstanding anything in this Act) the exclusive Legislative Authority of the Parliament of Canada extends to all Matters coming within the Classes of Subjects next hereinafter enumerated; that is to say...""  Per section 92 ""In each Province the Legislature may exclusively make Laws in relation to Matters coming within the Classes of Subjects next hereinafter enumerated; that is to say...""  To overcome jurisdictional problems constitutional amendments were enacted in respect of non-renewable natural resources, forestry resources and electrical energy (1982), old age pensions and supplementary benefits (1951), etc.  There is overlap.  The Canada Health Act represents a classic exercise of the federal spending power - meet conditions or fed funding is withheld.

Please cite, anywhere, within the CRCP or CRPC there is any language that governs how an attorney is expected to communicate with the media. You can't - it doesn't exist. Is he guilty of being a jerk in the Court of Public Opinion? Absolutely. That means absolutely nothing to OAR, nor should it. Colorado Rules of Professional Conduct deal with, and with no shortage of specificity: how attorneys are to confer and communicate with each other, how attorneys must communicate with their client, how attorneys must communicate with an opposing party not represented by counsel, and the protocol for comporting with courtroom-specific behavior. The flipping off of a reporter, though morally improper, is not per-se (it's protected speech) obscene; hence there is not even 'moral turpitude' issue that OAR could assume any jurisdiction over to even begin an investigation. Had the attorney made the gesture in court, that's a different story, as the threshold for contemptable civil obscenity is lower.

It's a cost shifting phenomenon that started in the late 70s, caused by Medicare and Medicaid.  These programs, when initially passed in the late 60s, were on a cost reimbursement basis.  Hospitals and physicians got reimbursed dollar for dollar for the actual costs incurred in providing services to program patients.  Like every government program, the spending got out of hand due expansions and overuse.  To get it under control,  program administrators started to artificially squeeze down provider rebursement over the decades.  Somewhere, probably in the late 80s, the amounts paid by these programs did not cover the providers' actual costs.  The providers responded by increasing the standard rates to make up for the losses.  Private insurers knew that providers preferred non-government patients, so started to negotiate discounts.  Providers agreed, for the most part, as long as they covered their actual costs.  And here we are today, with the high standard rates.

During the first decade plus of this century, Portland added hundreds of thousands of people and jobs without seeing any increase in automobile traffic. The exception proves the rule here; more people does not necessarily mean more congestion. It really depends on several factors. Unfortunately, Eugene is failing on all of those factors.  Our roadways are so uninviting to walk and cycle on that we have lost 37% of our cyclists back into cars over the past six years. I wonder if we will ever have any traffic law enforcement or sensible traffic diversions and signal cycles. Heck, I'd settle for not being harassed by the drunks who are living on the bike paths.  Our mass transit system is a near-complete failure. We have encouraged the placement of nearly all our destination shopping facilities to near-freeway locations and we never but never do anything to inhibit the driving of the suburbanites.  We have tremendous potential, but our reality is no where near it.

My daughter got very sick over Christmas break. She was fine at bedtime, and 3 hours later 105 and climbing fever, barely walk, shaking, clammy, hallucinating, incoherent, vomitting, severe migraine, in tremendous pain, weak and I was terrified. 3 am in the ER and being told they need to take her cerebral fluid to test for meningitis. She had viral meningitis and other undiagnosed illnesses they still don't know what all she had. Thank God we are 10 minutes from the hospital and they have a wonderful ICU staff who took amazing care of her. She was a very sick little girl and we have no idea how she got sick. We don't know anyone who had been sick, no one else in our family got sick. I took care of her and slept in ICU for a week, so even with very close contact and body fluids I never got sick. So simply being around someone doesn't necessarily mean you are at risk. I can't imagine suddenly losing a child. I recommend spinal taps if Doctors think your child could have meningitis.

I disagree that sport hunting should be banned--maybe you mean trophy hunting where the meat isn't utilized and all the 'hunters' are interested in is the antlers or hide of the animal.  Sport hunting is a great way for many households to get healthy, lean meat at a low cost and with no detrimental effects on wildlife populations (in most cases). You mention failures in the Lower 48, but the reality is that wildlife populations down there are doing great and being harvested sustainably. Whitetail deer, black bear, and grizzly bear numbers are the highest they have been in a hundred years.  Overpopulated even!  Also, the money that sport hunters spend on licenses and gear (Pittman-Robertson Act) goes right back to conservation efforts, habitat improvement, and acquisition and protection of lands for wildlife habitat.

Statues are a matter of what parts of history we honour and what parts we regret. By extension, today, we need to know who our friends are and who are adversaries are. Canada's crude oil exports in 2104 was around 2.85 million barrels ""per day"".

When I did Crow Pass in 2013, the water was above my waist. I had expected knee high water and wasn't prepared for how wide the crossing was. My two hiking partners and I teamed up with 2 other groups so there was 7 of us linking arms to do the crossing. It was going well until the dog of one of the other girls started getting swept away. She jumped for the dog and broke the chain. The one end of the chain started going down. It was pretty scary trying to regain balance when your feet are numb from the cold and there are large cobbles that move under your feet. In retrospect, I wouldn't cross it that high again but we had prepared for a long day hike not an overnighter. It is an epic hike but the river crossing was much more dangerous than I had imagined. Don't underestimate it and call the Eagle River Nature center to get River conditions before you go.

""The state response will help determine whether new companies will be able to establish a strong presence on the North Slope in competition with ConocoPhillips, BP and Exxon.""   The cartel on the slope decides who it`s competition is on the slope. They control access to the oil/gas/water separation and treatment facilities. And that`s the way it`s been since first oil. The same three companies own the rights to Prudhoe oil and gas, the same three control capacity in the system as well as own the TAPS oil line to Valdez. They also own the deep water shipping facilities.  That`s a hard monopoly for even the state, let alone a subsidized Caelus, to crack, without incurring what in the past was usurious costs to explorers/developers (now the state!). SB21 perpetuated that stranglehold on the bulk of the state`s oil resource development by the three remaining cartel members who signed the ""Prudhoe Bay Joint-operating-Unit Agreement, which gives each one a veto over the other two.

It is a huge issue that in Canada we allow some of our largest companies to continue with a system of dual categories of shares (voting and non voting). By doing so we allow some very wealthy families to continue to operate their businesses as if they were still the 100% shareholder and risk taker and this clearly does not benefit anybody except these families. The rest of us, if we invest in theses companies (either directly or through our pension plans and mutual funds) are simply being taken advantage of. The families can continue their own agendas with other people's money and this is not in the interests of the shareholders or the employees. Bombardier is not the only example of this problem in Canada - Canadian Tire and several other large companies are also controlled through a system of voting and non voting shares. The politicians have to stop supporting this practice - at the very least they need to stop subsidizing companies that operate in this manner.

Hi Gladys,  A civil comment can still be angry and passionate, but can't include threats, personal attacks, name-calling, racial slurs, doxxing/de-anonymizing (revealing personal information about another commenter, including their real name, home address, phone number, etc.) and obvious spam.  Also, your account won't be restricted until you've received multiple warnings.  For any comment, the answers to the first question, ""is this a good comment?"" only affect a comment's ranking when sorted by ""highest-rated"" (which is a combination of the yes/no/sorta votes and ""likes"" received).  The answers to the ""is it civil?"" question are only yes/no, and do affect whether a comment is published. A comment can be reviewed by up to 5 people.  These restrictions may seem unfair, especially when the people receiving them post perfectly fine and often very valuable comments themselves. But the voting aspect of the system is really crucial to setting the community standard.
